awd_titl_txt: Conformational Effects on the Gas-Phase Acidities of Biopolymers
awd_abstract_narration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Jianhua Ren of the University of the Pacific and her graduate and undergraduate research students are investigating the conformational effects on the gas-phase acidities of important biopolymers.  Specifically, Prof. Ren and her group will: (1)  Construct quantitative correlations between the gas-phase acidities and the conformations of a large number of peptides, including peptides containing unnatural amino acids; (2) investigate the effects on the gas-phase acidities of peptides containing D-amino acids; and (3) examine the helix conformational effects on the gas-phase acidities of peptoid polymers.  Prof. Ren and her researchers will carry out these studies using a variety of mass-spectrometry methods.

The ultimate goal of the work by Professor Ren and her group is to develop better models for understanding the acid-base properties of proteins.  The acid-base properties of proteins have a profound impact on the reactivity of proteins (enzymes), and the overall acidity of peptide groups in a protein are influenced by a myriad of subtle electrostatic effects.  Dr. Ren is trying to unravel the relative contributions of these subtle effects.   Along the way, Prof. Ren will train a very large number of undergraduate and graduate (MS) student researchers in the important area of biological mass spectrometry, after which they will enter the technological and medical workforce.

por.por_cntn:
Our research focused on investigating how the intrinsic chemical properties of biopolymers are correlated to their structural features, especially their conformations or three-dimensional shapes.  We have developed protocols to synthesize peptides and peptide-mimicking polymers, known as peptoids.  We have created a comprehensive investigation approach, which includes measuring the intrinsic acidity and basicity, as well as relevant chemical properties by using various mass spectrometry methods, examining the structural features by employing infrared multiple photon dissociation ion spectrometry techniques, and calculating the conformations and theoretical thermochemical properties via computational studies.  We have studied a library of oligopeptides containing either an acidic or a basic probe residue. Our study has produced high quality experimental and theoretical data addressing how conformational changes can influence the acid-base properties of peptides in a solvent-free environment. The findings greatly help to enhance the understanding of the ion chemistry of peptides and proteins.  The knowledge can be used as a valuable guide for engineering biopolymers with specific functional active sites.  We have designed and studied a series of model peptoids.  Our study has produced original experimental results showing the patterns of peptoid dissociation in the gas-phase.  The findings contribute to the body of knowledge about the ion chemistry of peptoids, which is largely understudied. We have demonstrated the utility of using peptoid ion fragmentation patterns to characterize the sequence and the structural features of the peptoids.  Our findings have been disseminated in 6 articles published in highly regarded journals and 38 conference presentations.

 

In the course of studing the intrinsic acid-base properties of peptides, we have found several interesting trends. First, oligopeptides with an acidic amino acid residue at the N-terminus have considerably greater gas-phase acidities than their analogues with an acidity residue at the C-terminus. Second, oligopeptides with a basic amino acid residue closest to the C-terminus have notably greater proton affinities than their counterparts with a basic residue closest to the C-terminus.  The difference in the degrees of the acidity or basicity is strongly correlated to the conformations of the peptides upon ionization in the gas-phase. Third, for oligopeptides containing a cysteine residue, changing the cysteine residue from the L-form to the D-form alters the degree of the gas-phase acidity.  The acidity alternation is likely due to the change in the conformations of the peptides upon ionization.

 

In the course of studing  peptoid ion dissociation using tandem mass spectrometry techniques, we have found some characteristic patterns.  First, singly protonated peptoids mainly fragment at the backbone amide bonds to produce highly-abundant C-terminal ions and lesser-abundant N-terminal ions. The bias toward the C-terminal ion formation is likely due to the great proton affinities of the C-terminal fragments.  Second, peptoids containing certain specific amine residues yield a series of secondary fragment ions corresponding to the loss of neutral molecules.  The pattern of neutral molecule loss is directly associated with the location of these specific amine residues.

 

We have successfully utilized the project as an educational platform to train graduate and undergraduate students as well as postdoctoral scholars in advanced research. This project has provided training opportunities for 1 postdoctoral scholar, 5 graduate students, and 26 undergraduate students. Among the group of undergraduate researchers, 62% are female and about 30% are underrepresented minorities.  The postdoctoral scholar and the graduate students have been well trained to propose new ideas, to design and to carry out new experiments, to share their findings with their peers, to present their results at national/international and regional conferences, and to write manuscripts.  They have also been trained to mentor undergraduate and high school research students and to organize the research laboratory.  Two graduate students have completed their degree studies with either a PhD degree or a Master?s degree, and have either assumed a research position in industry or gone on to pursue a PhD degree at another university, respectively. The undergraduate students have been trained through a peer-mentoring activity and have gained valuable hands-on experience in peptide synthesis, mass spectrometry analysis, and molecular modeling. Upon graduation, all undergraduate students have either gone to graduate schools or professional schools or have been employed as professionals in hospitals and in industry. Our research team has given numerous oral and poster presentations at national/international and regional conferences, and most of the presenters are graduate and undergraduate students. We have organized outreach activities during each summer by inviting local high school students to join our research team.  We have hosted 9 high school research students, including 5 from the American Chemical Society?s Project SEED program. Upon graduation from high schools, the students have gone to colleges and universities.
